'']] 'Phylloclades' and 'cladodes' are flattened, photosynthetic shoots, which
are modified branches. The two terms are used differently or interchangeably by
different authors. [[Phyllocladus]], a genus of conifer, is named after these
structures. Phylloclades/cladodes have been identified in fossils dating from as
early as the Permian.

By one definition, phylloclades are a subset of cladodes, those that greatly
resemble or perform the function of leaves, as in Butcher's broom
(Ruscus aculeatus) as well as [[Phyllanthus]] and some [[Asparagus]] species.

By an alternative definition, cladodes are distinguished by their limited
growth and that they involve only one or two internodes. By this
definition, some of the most leaf-like structures are cladodes, rather than
phylloclades. By that definition, Phyllanthus has phylloclades, but Ruscus and
Asparagus have cladodes.
